column1: Baron Carrickfergus is a title in the peerage of the United Kingdom
column2: referring to Carrickfergus in County Antrim
column7: who was granted the title as a personal gift
column9: on the day of his marriage to Catherine Middleton. On the same day he was also created Duke of Cambridge and Earl of Strathearn
column10: with his bride becoming "Her Royal Highness The Duchess of Cambridge" as well as Countess of Strathearn and Baroness Carrickfergus as a result of the marriage. Traditionally
column11: when male members of the British royal family marry
column12: they are granted at least one peerage. Catherine uses the title "Lady Carrickfergus" in a fuller version of her titles and styles
column13: Her Royal Highness The Duchess of Cambridge
column14: Countess of Strathearn and Baroness Carrickfergus.

column3: had previously existed between 1841 and 1883. In 1841
column6: was created by Queen Victoria as Baron Ennishowen and Carrickfergus
column11: in the Peerage of the United Kingdom. When he died in 1883
column12: the Barony of Ennishowen and Carrickfergus became extinct; the Marquessate of Donegall was inherited by his brother
column13: Lord Edward Chichester.Carrickfergus is the oldest town in County Antrim. It has been a major port and town in the Province of Ulster for centuries. Its name translated from Irish means "Rock of Fergus"
column14: and it is an older settlement than the capital city of Northern Ireland
column15: Belfast. Carrickfergus's main feature is Carrickfergus Castle
column16: on the north shore of the Belfast Lough
column17: which was built around 1180 by John de Courcy.
